passages.trns: Before the modern world had begun, there was only water and air.

passages.trns: There existed a stark division bounded only by the ocean's surface: above the surface, stretched infinitely upwards, was the light blue of sky, and below the surface, stretched infinitely downwards, was the dark blue of sea.
passages.text: Sohē nomēn butla namurpārra mo beih rih² sildūr: t²ē ne rih²met²en, otletī sulī sū met²en, tīrōn²sarrēn, t²ē ne rih²sār, otletī sulī sū sār, masouhresarrēn.

passages.trns: The sea was content in the arrangement, because the whole of the sky was laid bare for her to see - but the sky, however, did not share the sentiment.
passages.text: Rozlē mās ya dēlun²kēn, ko cēz ollā passa tiyen millē ne ate rān ya em²ā - īs nūhuē paquē on tiyen ten serlikīn.

passages.trns: The sea's water was naturally murky, and the blue light of the sky could not penetrate it more than a few paces.

passages.trns: The sky knew that the sea must be harboring an infinite abyss of mysteries beneath her surface, and grew more and more jealous as millenia passed by.

passages.expl: The language traditionally uses a base-20 system, and bāmissīn uses the root bā, the multiplier for thousands' place. While in modern speech, the base-20 system has been generally overridden by an imported, European base-10 model.

passages.trns: The sky soon developed a plan by which he would take the sea's waters for his own.

passages.trns: As it sank, the sea took pity on the stone, for it had once been made from her sand and smoothed the rough edges created so haphazardly by the winds.
passages.text: Akomat²ē, ne sāpit²ā izen, mās ko cēz tanrecā tinkoī tō kela rān in ixākseyē marrami pobum²a mezreca ān sapenilī mo rotosin.

passages.text: Oandequē izen rah²m²ī sū istatūn t²a nuzhuatān ne aldā ān moron tauntēs.

passages.trns: The great serpent was cursed by the wind by which it had been made, and unlike for the fish that swam before it, the water was poisonous to breath.
passages.text: Secrē on nuzhuatān mo rotōs mo-tanreca, in sīhasm²ē īs-ko ser t²ā ya oltumi dole ne aten alūn ya tokā.
passages.phnt: ˈsɛt͜ʃreː ɔn̥ ˈnʊt͜swatan̥ mo roˈtos mo ˈtɑnret͜ʃa ɪn̥ ˈsiʔɑsmeː is ko sɛr̥ taː ʝa ˈɔl̥tumi ˈðole ne ˈatən̥ aˈlun̥ ʝa toˈkaː
data: sec-r-ē               on        nuz-huata-:n           mo   roto<:>s       mo=tan-r-ec-a                    in  sīhas-m²-ē             īs=ko       ser-Ø         t²-ā            ya   oltu-mi        dol-e           ne   at-en            alu-:n          ya   Ø-tok-ā

passages.trns: He was forced to breach the surface - and though fortunately the storm had begun to fade by this time - he could never return to the deep.
passages.text: Xerā alen huelquā sū rit²en - aldowcē inquē zīasi kem²ī tauntēs ne ten lōn - īs lem²asē alen sū tūrrēn sicē.

passages.trns: The great serpent swam into existence a great whirlpool, that sucked from the bottom of the ocean a mountain on which the he could lay down his land.
passages.text: Tanē nuzhuatān dolī sū sohīn eppalutlepōn nuza, in eppe tō sildurkotōn noctizen ne-pan²yasa alen omazū.

passages.trns: And so as the summit broke the surface of the water, the first island was made.
passages.text: Mezrē inquē ne picā akēx alurit²en kisren tineza.

passages.trns: The land was barren expanse of sand, and the great serpent breathed life into it, shedding his scales to plant the seeds of colorful flowers and grasses that would come to decorate his domain.
passages.text: T²ē mazūen kelakabūn norda, in tokē sū tīen nuzhuatān, inait²ī alen obiseus ya īhhuot²ā tezās somomi tōlleka in pexin mirkelatena dahzec alen.

passages.trns: The scales grew and became the leaves of trees and petals of flowers, blossoming in the light of the now clear sky.
passages.text: Osahpē bisesin in yeh²latē muōlu siphuen in atat²u somomi; kukē ne rō tiyen narlateca nehloī.

passages.trns: When he saw his work as complete, he hoarded himself into his garden, vanishing from the view of both the sky and sea.
passages.text: Osūsakē ne em²ā alen kōh²recā os on et²ah² sū oihuot²elar; istlē tō em²i mer tiyen in mās.
